website_summaries.verdict: Nicely balanced, comfortable and well-designed, the Adonit Jot Touch is an excellent pressure-sensitive stylus for the iPad.
pros: The Adonit Jot Touch feels very good and delivers excellent pressure-sensitivity performance with no lag
cons: It doesn't have a travel case or spare nibs, and while the USB power charger is cleverly designed, it's likely easily lost

customer_reviews.title: Compatibility with iOS has fallen behind. This will not work on iPad running iOS 10.2
customer_reviews.text: No longer works, with iPad Air 2 or iPad Mini 3 both running iOS 10.2. Some of the responses here are 3 years old now and still no fix. Tech Support seems to be fielding these calls one by one but I am not getting the best, (none really) performance from my $99.00 stylus. Look at something else but keep in mind, Adonit can't keep up with the updates making your expensive purchase a waste.
customer_reviews.author: Darko

customer_reviews.title: I tried to like this with my ipad air 2 but some of ...
customer_reviews.text: I tried to like this with my ipad air 2 but some of the time, the stylus would not register. I was using it with a couple of different apps but primarily notes plus and with it set to palm rejection/stylus mode, numerous times per sentence, the stylus would not register on the screen. I ended up sending it back and gave up on these expensive bluetooth styluses in favor of a basic rubber tip stylus (the Elago slim) which works perfectly and is super affordable and comes with an extra tip. I will say though that when the Adonit worked, it was really good but it was FAR too inconsistent for me to deal with on a daily basis.
customer_reviews.author: Drew Lankford

customer_reviews.title: BEFORE YOU BUY! WARNING!! NOT FOR THE IPAD AIR 2!!!
customer_reviews.text: this stylus DOES NOT work with the Apple IPad Air 2. I used it on the following apps: procreate, Adobe SketchBook, Sketches, Adobe Draw, and Adobe Sketch. The stylus would start to draw your line but the stop working; other times it wouldn't even start at all. Adonit's website says the problem is with Apple's new thinner screen technology, and that they are working on a SDK to fix the issue. I believe they should make this clear on there website and on this Amazon page that the stylus does not work properly with the IPad Air 2 yet.
customer_reviews.author: 03andrew77

customer_reviews.title: I would not recommend this product
customer_reviews.text: Disappointing. I use an Ipad air gen 1 with the photoshop sketch app. Palm rejection is a joke even with a drawing glove on. The "pixel" point accuracy that it claims is hit or miss. I'll be drawing a line and the start point is far away from where I began. I have tried re syncing it multiple times with no success of fixing my issues. I would not recommend this product.
customer_reviews.author: jack

customer_reviews.title: Waste of money.
customer_reviews.text: (This review is for having used it on the iPad Air 2) I'm not an artist or anything; I got this hoping I'd be able to use it for writing. I was not. In a word, this thing is terrible—with or without paired apps. When it's not inaccurate, it's skipping almost entirely at random, no matter how you decide to hold it and no matter what your settings are set to for how you hold it. I'm not even going to bother talking about palm rejection because it can't even do stylus recognition in the first place.
customer_reviews.author: Chris

customer_reviews.title: I had the older version of the Adonit Jot Pro previously and thought that I wouldn't be disappointed by getting a nicer stylus f
customer_reviews.text: I have an iPad Air and after reading reviews I decided to try this stylus. I had the older version of the Adonit Jot Pro previously and thought that I wouldn't be disappointed by getting a nicer stylus from the same company, but it really sucked. You have to press extremely hard to get it to work and then there is some lag time. After trying multiple styluses along with this one, I ended up with keeping the newest version of the Adonit Jot Pro (and a plus is that it is less than half the price of this one)
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: No where near worth the $100
customer_reviews.text: I have been using the AJT with iPad Air 2 and numerous apps including: procreate, sketchbookX, inked, pixelmatr, skitch, bamboo paper, 53 paper, woodnotes, note shelf, and penultimate. The ADJ is awful and not worth your time if you're looking to use it on the iPad Air 2 for notes or sketching. Consistent problems: -often will not initiate ink when I put the pen to the iPad -often will not inking while I am shading forcing me to pick up the pen and set it down again to make it ink again -sometimes does not ink accurately
customer_reviews.author: samueltlogan

customer_reviews.title: It's great on the go
customer_reviews.text: I just want to say that offset is simply a fact of life with these tools. This ain't no cintiq, but because of this little sucker I'll probably refrain from buying a cintiq. It's great on the go, has an excellent range of pressure, and works like a dream with Procreate. While I still do a majority of my work at the desk with my Intuos Pro, I'm still happy to bust this out whenever I'm away from my workstation! I just wish the palm rejection problem...wasn't a thing. There's glove-made solutions for it, but they aren't perfect either.
customer_reviews.author: Katherine Van Buren

customer_reviews.title: used to be $120  but the price has dropped by two-thirds for a reason

customer_reviews.author: Maxxavier

customer_reviews.title: Needs an update
customer_reviews.text: When I bought this to go with my new iPad Air 2 I did not know about the software issues. The new iPad refreshes its screen nearly constantly and it's causing the stylus to lose contact. Adonis, to be fair, is aware of the problem and is busy working on a fix and I sure I will LOVE the stylus when it's fixed, but for right now if you're looking for a stylus for the new iPad Air 2 then you might want to wait until the issues are resolved.
customer_reviews.author: frolic_about

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Choice
customer_reviews.text: I started using the jot touch for note taking instead of the classic rubber stylus. I get to say the the exchange is in the right direction. The pen is more precise and comfortable to the hand. One quick advice: drop the penultimate app. In spite of being partnered with Adonit, the app performance is awful. Is far from being precise. One thing I am disappointed is that notability does not support all the functionalities of the pen. However the app and the pen have good interaction. Now I'm using Goodnotes 4 and both the pen and the app work smoothly together.
customer_reviews.author: R. Solorzano

customer_reviews.title: Great When It Works, Not As Accurate As Promised
customer_reviews.text: The Adonit Jot Touch with Pixelpoint is a great stylus on paper. When it comes to actually using it, it's been either hit or miss. The pen randomly decides not to register on my iPad screen, and the image I'm drawing appears slightly above where the pen is touching the screen. The battery life is great on this device, and the magnetic charging system works great. It feels pretty good to hold as the size and weight are good...I just wish the tip would be more accurate. I find myself using my old Adonit Jot Pro instead most of the time.
customer_reviews.author: Micah T

customer_reviews.title: I'd strongly recommend saving the money and putting it towards a more ...
customer_reviews.text: If you plan on using this for art, I'd strongly recommend saving the money and putting it towards a more useful tool. I found it to be so buggy and poorly support to the point of being nearly useless compared to just using a normal stylus.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good, but not on iPad Air 2
customer_reviews.text: Great build quality and battery life. It just didn't work well with the iPad Air 2. I understand this is mostly because of the change screen technology that Apple used but it was disappointing nonetheless. Lines would skip and the offset would sometimes vary wildly. My Jot Pro works better in all situations and costs significantly less. I'd give a lower rating but I think most connected styli suffer in this regard in the Air 2...
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: I can only say its a missed opportunity on a potentially terrific product.
customer_reviews.text: purchased it to use with ipad air 2. As of right now, the product is unusable for sketching or painting. When trying to draw arcs, curves, ellipses, circles, only a jagged line appears. Contacted Adonit, reply is they were working on it, with no ETA of resolving the problem. Until then, I can only say its a missed opportunity on a potentially terrific product.
customer_reviews.author: Thang Le

customer_reviews.title: Not meant for me...
customer_reviews.text: I really wanted to like this, but it just doesn't fit my purpose. I take a lot of notes on my iPad and this stylus unfortunately isn't made for speed. It works great for normal-slow writing but if you write fast (or small) then it will just lead to frustration, it becomes too sensitive. Also it is completely dependent on only a couple third party note taking Apps, which in my opinion are not in the top echelon of those available (for note taking/pdf editing). If they were able to partner with better Apps, or create a little more robust software recognition (maybe take writing speed into account) I would rate it higher.
customer_reviews.author: David Friedlander

customer_reviews.title: Meh
customer_reviews.text: Highly accurate 90% of the time! but I already have something that is 100% accurate...my old fashioned pen. Palm rejection feature worked well with the right app (GoodNotes). Undo/redo buttons are a nifty feature. I bought every note taking app available on the App Store hoping I could find a bearable writing experience, to no avail. GoodNotes was by far the best, if not the most feature rich, but I still suffered from accuracy issues. The pen also makes too much noise against the glass while writing, which was a deal breaker for me. Returned.
customer_reviews.author: Seth R Brown

customer_reviews.title: Fell in love
customer_reviews.text: I absolutely love this stylus. It is definitely worth the price with everything it can do. You will need to download the apps that are affiliated with the stylus. This stylus made writing papers for college become A LOT easier! The fact that you can write you notes and transfer it to text and email it to yourself is awesome! LOVE IT! I haven't had a problem with it so far and it charges pretty fast. Love that I don't have to buy batteries for this kind. :)

customer_reviews.author: Anastasiya Kaspruk

customer_reviews.title: What a disappointment. Wildly inaccurate!
customer_reviews.text: Wow. What a disappointment. The pen feels great, but it's so wildly inaccurate that it's actually unusable. Holding the stylus as you would a normal ink pen, the touch position seems to vary from 3mm to a full cm away from the actual point where the tip touches the screen. I'm ambidextrous and I've tried both left and right handed with the same results. I see no instructions on how to calibrate it so the tip is actually the touch point. Even holding the stylus straight up and down it's still over a mm off. For the price, I expected it to work better than the $5 stylus with the big rubbery end. It doesn't.
customer_reviews.author: UselessRob

customer_reviews.title: Maybe the problem was with my Adonit Jot Touch specifically ...
customer_reviews.text: Maybe the problem was with my Adonit Jot Touch specifically, but as of this review, it's not a product that I can stand behind. The stylus presented a huge offset when used with my iPad 2, and input lag was a major problem. The pen would shut off at times during use and after syncing to compatible apps such as Penultimate, the connection would get lost and I would be forced to re-sync. The pen was more of a burden than a tool of productivity, so I was forced to return it to Amazon. Hopefully, future iterations address some of the serious, aforementioned issues or Adonit will have trouble stacking up to its major competitors, such as the Apple Pencil.
customer_reviews.author: Yancy Carrasco

customer_reviews.title: Great Stylus (as long as you use the right apps)
customer_reviews.text: This stylus is excellent for note taking on the iPad. However, it depends heavily on the app that you use. I had great success with Noteshelf: no lag, accurate line placement, and perfect palm rejection. Penultimate and GoodNotes on the other hand, while ostensibly supporting the stylus had terrible issues with palm rejection and inaccuracy. If you want to use this stylus, make sure you use Noteshelf or Adobe Sketch/Line which work perfectly with it.
